dialogues.text: Took six very expensive lawyers to weasel us out of it.  An inch from bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moral of the story?  When you marry a tour guide.  Confine his authority to mixing the drinks.  Same again, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And holds out her glass.  Billy looks out to sea.  Like h heard this. QUOYLE (cheerful) So.  What brings you folks up from Long Island?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  While husband and wife glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dining salon needs refitting. And the best custom yacht upholsterer in the Northern Hemisphere just moved here.  I was forced.  To follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to Quoyle.  Who just gapes at her.  Open-mouthe QUOYLE (softly) Oh.  My.  God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle enters, impressed by the progress of the renovatio Windows are in, walls patched, floor sanded, lights are w Through the place into... ...the kitchen, which is in surprisingly usable shape.  A alone at a butcher block table with a set of ledgers spre her.  A large mug of tea.  A bottle of Bushmill's Irish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a woman of mystery, Aunt. Mystery and surprise. AGNIS (still working) Silver Melville says you was out there.  Be nice in yer story, she's payin' for a piece of this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said upholstery.  Never said yacht uphol...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...never said not.  Ask better questions, you got a chance fer better answers.  Got my shop set up in Killick-Claw, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks up.  Sees he's dazzled by how she moves right along

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two good workers.  Mrs. Mavis Bangs is an old plow horse like m'self.  But Dawn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn's young and on the sexy side.  You oughta drop by and say hullo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He absorbs that.  How fast can he change the subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Bunny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis looks at him.  Reaches for the Bushmill's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, in what will soon become her room.  She'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours some whiskey into her tea cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little early in the day f...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren died today.  That's what that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks the whiskey.  Stares straight in his eyes.  Sees h The honesty in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis deciding.  Whether to tell him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to live with someone named Warren.  Died of cancer, after nine years together.  Dearest soul on this earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle shocked.  What can he say?  His empathy so naked, even Agnis has to soften her voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went from the funeral, and bought that dog.  Named her Warren.  Just so I could say the name a hunnerd times a day.  Women are foolish, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good moment for them.  It holds a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny wants to bury the dog with me.  But I told her I'd rather do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle nods.  Rises slowly.  He'd better go to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some advice about the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get down on her level, the way you do.  She'll never respect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny sits on the floor in dim light, wearing an enormous sweatshirt.  Obviously dad's.  Her naked Barbies sit in a circle watching her braid a meticulous loop out of the pa foil from chewing gum wrappers.  Quoyle enters, and sits beside her.  Watches in silence, as she works. BUNNY (not looking up) Warren died today.  She's not coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tears.  Just a hollow sound in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what she means.  Strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another necklace, huh?  Can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  He looks at the Barbies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to take my clothes off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him.  Straight to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look better with 'em on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes back to work.  He watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.  You do look good in blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle driving the wagon, Dennis at his side.  Up ahead o road, two figures.  Herry holds tight to his mom's hand. pulls over, and they stop.  Wavey squints at him, against

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give you folks a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That extra beat before she says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're enjoyin' the walk, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't smile.  Doesn't look angry either.  Just comforta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  My aunt can't bring Bunny to the daycare, she's got her shop now. But I worked it out with my boss.  So I'll be bringin' her come next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love to have her.  I'm sorry, Mr. Quoyle, about the other time. Women can be moody, you know.  And temperamental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she smiles.  One-tenth power.  Still a dazzler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the best ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she like that?  Hard to tell.  She looks around him..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Dennis.  Give our respects to Beety and Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves, will do.  She takes Herry's hand, starts off do road.  Quoyle sits and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent posture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle looks over.  His pal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rear ANGLE of Agnis, walking over stones to the edge of t carrying something in her arms.  Walking to meet the sun, gives its last to the shimmering water.  REVERSE ANGLE to ...she carries her old dog.  On a clean sheet.  Rests the gently down.  The incoming tide laps over.  The sheet bil it.  She takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a good girl, Warren, no trouble a'tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surf rolls out.  Swims back in.  Flows around her friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outhouse stands unobtrusively near the edge of the cli Agnis alone, approaching.  Something in her hand.  As she the outhouse, we see it is... ...the ziploc bag.  With her brother's ashes.  She gazes the house now.  Then, at the bag... AGNIS (cold, low) Hope ya like.  What we done with the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door, enters.  Stares down into the deep ho Unzips the bag, and... ...TIPS the ashes DOWN INTO the hole.  Watch them in SLO- falling free.  Hear the rustle of Agnis lifting her skirt CLOSE ANGLE on Agnis' face.  Staring out at the sea throu crack in the outhouse wall.  HEAR the splatter as she voi herself. AGNIS (a murmur) Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daycare in progress.  The comfy parlor has been given ove kids.  A wall of Polaroids of each child faces a map of Newfoundland with drawings of moose, caribou, and lobster Herry sits alone in a doorway, watching with big eyes as. ...Quoyle, Bunny astride his back, RAMPAGES around the pa all fours, SNORTING like a crazed boar.  The kids are squ delighted, making excited little runs at him, swatting hi throw pillows and rolled-up sweaters.  Thrill of the hunt Wavey comes through the doorway, drying her hands, just b where her boy sits.  Quoyle doesn't see her, he's thrashi bellowing, lost in the game.  She watches, for a long bea leans down to Herry. WAVEY (a whisper) Go on.  Get the pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herry grins like the devil.  Dashes off to PLOW INTO the knocking them sprawling.  Kids PILING on. Wavey's unseen smile.  The start of something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Quoyle.  He is happily washing a mountain of dis cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Newfie drills another hole in the ice, aways off from the first one.  Once again, the voice booms, NO FISH DOWN HERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to see Wavey beside him.  She's drying what he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he moves way down the ice. Drills another hole.  Voice comes again, I SAID, NO FISH DOWN HERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't look at each other.  Poker-faced, just alike, side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newfie looks around.  Still nobody.  Hollers, WHO ARE YA? THE VOICE O' GOD?  Voice comes back, NO!  THE ARENA MANAGER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't help but snort out a chuckle of his own.  Sneaks over at her, and she... ...laughs out loud.  Healthy.  Sexy, even.  But from the guesses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard it before, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over at him.  Her eyes dance a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, passion in performance. Beats the element of surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is lost in those eyes.  Knows it's showing.  Glanc where... ...Bunny sits in a corner.  Reading to a rapt Herry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh.  I'm teaching Herry to read. Just like I did Warren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he learnin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny looks over at him.  He is so dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First is the teaching part.  The learning comes later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herry nods.  Later.  And out of the blue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wavey?  Now are the berries ready to pick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle looks over to the woman.  But instead of Wavey, he PETAL, staring at him with slow predatory heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to pick my berries, do you. Should I climb right up on this sink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, once more she is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost.  Almost ready.  You know, it's all about timing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle.  Takes note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle alone in the office, pretending to peck away at a Actually, he's looking... ...through the window.  Where Jack Buggit, Tert Card, Bil and Nutbeem are all circling around a small, roughly-made attached to its rented trailer.  They are talking to each learned tones.  A Talmudic chat.  And... ...in they come.  First through the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's yer boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One question remains.  Why. Is that.  Yer boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.  He looks from one face to another.  Even Billy is irritated.  Nutbeem gazes down, embarrassed for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  A boat's a boa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shit boat.  Best thing, get rid of it some dark night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle can't believe this.  Hot shame burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go hire Alvin Yark to build ya a sweet little rodney.  This thing's a wallowing cockeyed bastard that'll sink in a bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And standing in the doorway, the scariest sight of all. Just shaking his head. JACK (sadly) You don't have the sense God gave a doughnut, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word from Sinai on Quoyle's worth.  A pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' fishin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the door with a SLAMM!  Quoyle stares hopelessly afte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't jump off a bridge over it. Anyone can make a brainless, asinine, devastatingly revealing blunder. QUOYLE (actually means this) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in th' furry pit of Newfie hell. Is this!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holds up some sheets of paper.  Photos of the Melvilles' botterjacht.  Reads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler's Barge...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That goes with the shipping news. Profile of a vessel in port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the car accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one I didn't do.  Mrs. Diddolate sprained her wrist.  Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Card still reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you didn't do the one Jack told yer to do, and you did one he don't know yer did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty mu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This copy.  Is worse.  Than yer boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up.  Equal parts disgust and delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack even sniffs this, he cuts you up fer lobster bait.  I've half a mind to run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle straightens his spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strides off for the door.  Turns back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for the part about you havin' half a mind?  No comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the door.  SLAMM harder than Jack's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle stumbling toward his wagon with vacant eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline.  Reporter Disembowels Self With Rusty Joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle in a carpenter's belt, climbing very carefully fro onto the roof.  His vertigo apparent as he keeps to his h knees, trying to fight the compulsion to look down.  Give it, peering from the corner of his eye down the cliff, th the sea so far below.  Not a good 1dea. Comes to the shingles.  Eases his way into a fearful crou Starts hammering.  And rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I completely understand, I would fire me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding, in time to the hammer strokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hammers LOUDER, speaking in rhythm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me a chance, and what happens?  I buy the wrong boat, I write the wrong story, I am the lowest form of alleged life.  In fact, your comment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was an insult to the doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear now what the hammering had masked.  Someone is reach top of the ladder, climbing onto the roof. Bunny.  Somehow she has managed to climb while carrying a on a plate.  And an open bottle of soda.  He stares at he uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Egg salad and Nehi grape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets them down.  Stands UP on the steep pitch. QUOYLE (shocked stupid) Baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're mine but I'll share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plate and bottle slip neatly OFF the roof and, aft noticeable beat, shatter softly far below.  Bunny's turn shocked.  She's contemplating going after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON'T MOVE!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that was a little loud.  It has also scared the kid her wits.  Quoyle regrets this.  Starts scooching awkward the slope, inches at a time... QUOYLE (too casual) We're gonna play Wait For Daddy. Can you play that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just staring over the side.  Hypnotized by the sigh slipping toward her.  Toward the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you don't move.  Until I get there.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer, reaching toward her back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then you win!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...GRABS her arm, she STARTLES, violently LURCHING, but h her to him.  Holds her to his heart.  Holds her.  He is b like a freight train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That.  Was so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Buggit enters with energy.  Looks around.  Billy's t Nutbeem's reading.  Quoyle is cleaning out his desk, pull off his little shelf to pack away.  Goofy photo of Bunny. child-made three-legged turtle.  Tiny padded box with wha be carefully-preserved empty eggshells. Jack heads toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did ya see the Hitler's barge piece, Jocko?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it.  And heard from some who'd done the same. (to Quoyle) Good.  Neatness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle turns.  Pretty much all his possessions are in a b cardboard box.  Jack peers into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reorganize.  Start over.  Good thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's smiling.  Like he's got the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing about the barge piece?  I just thought it'd perk up th...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got six phone calls 'bout that piece.  Six.  That'd be like half a million calls in Toronto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grasps Quoyle around the back of the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People liked it, old son.  Crowd went down to the dock t'see the thing, but it'd already pulled out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle stares, slack-faced into the elfin eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course you don't know anything about boats, but that's entertaining, too.  So go ahead with it.  That's the kinda stuff I want, see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now, Card's jaw is scraping his boot tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, you write a column every week.  The Shipping News.  Gonna order you a computer and everything.  And y'know the beauty part...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to tell Card all over again, cause he's already eavesdroppin'.  So I'm free to take m'leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' fishin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  You've an instinct for character and idiosyncrasy, old son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wink.  He heads toward the door.  And never looking at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zip yer fly, Card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Card looks down.  He zips up, as the door slams.  Billy P sends Quoyle a thumbs-up, without turning.  Nutbeem clasp hands above his head, like a winning prizefighter. Quoyle slides a sheet of paper into his typewriter.  Star

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-eight years.  First time anybody said you done it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman looks up from her stitching.  She is solidly buil 60, Emily Dickinson hair.  A cheerful, calmly butch way a Trustworthy eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nephew, this is Mavis Bangs.  A real professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis holds out a hearty hand.  Agnis is showing him the cutting table, two sewing stations.  Billowing sailcloth the windows.  Racks of leathers and fabrics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Dawn Budgel.  She's a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn, once described by Agnis as young and on the sexy si that.  Red lipstick and nails.  Her eyes float up in a wa suggests reflexive sensuality.  Agnis nods to her, and th reaches a slender pale hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis is always saying such...things about you.  It's nice to fit a man. With the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as she releases his hand, her eyes flick to Agnis.  S conspiracy there.  Quoyle follows his aunt back to the bi table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just, uh, came to see if you'd heard abou..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silver Melville?  Snuck off in the night, they did.  Not a penny paid for all we done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shows him sheets of baby blue leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd installed the banquettes in her salon.  Three of the chairs done and delivered, three to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Points to them.  A neat row by the makeshift kitchenette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's.  That's just terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Agnis is thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange.  Leavin' the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he glances off, he sees Dawn across the way.  Her hiked up, as if she were adjusting a stocking. She isn't wearing any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billowy clouds frame a languid KITE, silver and sleek, da way and that.  Graceful, in command of the currents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERRY PROWSE!  LOOK HOW WELL YOUR KITE IS DOING!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See her now, seated atop a grassy slope.  It is she who h string, and her boy is way down at the bottom of the hill Bunny.  Blue jumper billowing, the girl is teaching him h necklaces from wildflowers and garbage bag twisty-ties. the naked Barbies watch with great attention.  The learni come later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARE YOU MAKING IT DANCE WITH YOUR THOUGHTS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this he looks up.  Serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEEP THINKING YOUR THOUGHTS! YOUR KITE IS DOING SO MUCH BETTER THAN MR. QUOYLE'S!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK slightly to reveal that Quoyle has been sitting beside her all along.  He holds the string of a big, glum hangs motionless in space with barely a flutter.  As she the kids, he stares at her, fixedly deciding whether to a QUOYLE (barely audible) Do you think Bunny's.  Strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wavey looks over.  Sees that he's worried half to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In New York.  They said she had a... personality disorder. WAVEY (softly) And it was named Petal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these hallucin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White Dog.  Sometimes with the Skinny Ghost.  Kids do things like that, it's called imagination.  Like the necklaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The necklaces, yeh.  A thought that frightens him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how many she makes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a skill, she's proud of it.  And she brings her dolls along.  And she looks good in blue.  And she wears a key for a good luck charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her kind smile.  No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's saving her mother a room. Did she tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wavey's slow nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She talks to her at night.  I can hear through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very quiet now.  The wind.  The kites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how kids think.  You have all those books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones I read to teach Herry. They don't make me an exp... QUOYLE (blurting) Just.  Is she okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was naked.  He swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean.  If you had to guess..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too serious a subject.  Too good a woman.  For an easy li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That child is the only friend my son ever had.  So she's strange, you bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swallows, too.  Her eyes are damp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that little girl.  And I will see to it.  That she's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold the look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't have to guess about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle RUNNING, huffing, through a bog with every color o imaginable.  Around another bend in the path.  Stops.  Ha knees. Listens.  Nothing.  Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IF YOU GUYS AREN'T CHASING ME, I'M GONNA BE COMPLETELY CHEESED OFF!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More nothing.  He trudges back the way he came.  Peeks ar bend to see... ...Bunny is teaching Berry to pick gooseberries.  This ti learning has started.  They are being very careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you pick enough, we can sell 'em for a thousand dollars.  And give it to Aunt Agnis to make up for those Staties who didn't pay h... BUNNY (means business) Then don't.  Slow us.  Down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle SLAPS his hands across his mouth.  Sorry!  He tipt Rounds a bend.  Walking faster now... Around another bend.  And stops.  Hold on his face.  REVE to take his view of... ...Petal, kneeling in a flimsy sundress, picking berries. Barefoot, her skirt hiked up, stained with berry juice. she turns to him... ...she is still Petal.  Her face is beautiful, and filled tender desire.  She looks at him the way he has always dr would.  He goes to... ...kneel beside her.  Touch her waist.  And now she is... ...another woman.  His hand is on Wavey's waist, and it c slowly away.  But her eyes are locked to his.  Making her WAVEY (very soft) Look.  I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even in kindness, he can smell rejection.  He starts to b but she takes his hand.  Holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want us.  To be friends, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, dumbly.  Of course.  Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And friends.  Need.  To understand each other. QUOYLE (so sorry) I understand.  Believe m...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband drowned.  Herry was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard for her.  He quiets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was two months old.  And Herold took the boat out.  Overnight.  To fish for haddock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I liked.  Haddock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, did I blow it.  Or can you still be my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Quoyle nods, sure.  I'll be your friend.  But wh sees is a lifetime of being Quoyle washing past his eyes. her murmur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from his heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking I'm sorry.  For everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up.  HEAR him stumble off.  HOLD on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grassy place above an empty sea.  The rest of the world Two figures climb the gentle hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doin' with the Tall and Quiet Woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy Crawford and me is doin' fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant Wavey Prowse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad used to say there's four women in every man's life.  The Stouthearted Woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that'd be Agnis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Maid in the Meadow... QUOYLE (has to think) Bunny I guess.  Weavin' a daisy-chain necklace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Tall and Quiet Woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  She does have that posture goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the Demon Lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this.  Quoyle's smile fades.  He looks away.  They've fence where blunt pickets enclose crosses and wooden mark fallen on the ground. BILLY (wistful) Me dad said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy finds the right marker.  Sets his satchel onto the Kneels.  His old fingers clear debris from painted words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me poor father.  Thirteen I was when he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears the thread of feeling in his simple words.  And more.  Withdraws two cans of paint from his bag.  One whi black.  Two brushes.  Lays them out carefully, for this t sacred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time I wonder.  Is this the last coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pries the lid off the tin of black.  And when he sees Quo eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's no one else to do it, y'see. QUOYLE (straight back) There is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An easy smile.  Stating the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man's face just stops.  The eyes sharpen.  Into a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you said.  There's no one else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if that were enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  If you wanna rest next to him.  I'll paint yours at the same time.  No extra trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stares at him.  Stares at him.  Clears his throat,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then better get Alvin Yark. T'build yer a real boat.  So yer'll be around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle exits the house, pulling on his jacket, and... ...stops.  Something laid across his threshold.  A long p TWINE has been placed there.  KNOTS tied evenly along its He glances back up to the second floor, thinking Bunny. the thing again.  Neat work.  Odd.  Slips it in his pocke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle now making his way down a steep primitive trail th vegetation.  The green house is far above him.  The shimm now just below.  This way down as treacherous as it is wo and Quoyle SLIPS in the tangle and wet, half-slides throu angelica stalks and patches of dogberry, suddenly... ...LOSING his balance, TUMBLING roughly down a stretch, r grasping a spruce trunk.  Pulling himself to his feet, he RUSTLING.  Looks up, just as... ...a WHITE DOG appears through the bushes.  Red eyes.  Li back.  A frozen second of mutual indecision, and Quoyle.. ...SCREAMS and falls on his butt.  The dog... ...TAKES OFF, bounding down a path we hadn't noticed.  To upright SILHOUETTE.  Who steps into sun just long enough become... ...a MAN, grizzled and scrawny and quick.  Gone in a flas skinny ghost.  And there, on his butt... ...Quoyle laughs softly.  How 'bout that?  Murmurs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attaway, girl.  You're smarter'n all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he climbs to his feet, he sees the rocky beach just be Squints, as if at something that doesn't belong.  We see ...a SUITCASE, washed up onto a tangle of rocks, just off ANGLE...Quoyle wading into the water.  Up to his knees, s sinks to his waist.  Stays upright.  Snatches the suitcas perch.  Brings it back to shore, holding it high.  Alread making the face of someone smelling something he'd rather He sets it down.  The face is worse.  His curiosity runni show, he unhooks the latch... ...and stops.  Because he's staring inside.  Suddenly, he and FLAILS back, his leg STRIKING the case, and out tumbl the wet ground... ...the head.  Of Bayonet Melville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three guys.  Three beers.  Five squidburgers (Quoyle like backups ready and waiting).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know none a that impresses Jack Buggit.  He's not one fer blatant ambition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle thinks better of his answer.  Chomps a bite instea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you don't recognize 'Human Head Packed in Satchel' as the most compelling piece ever to appear in... CARD (snorts) Even if.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...takes his hand from his greasy burger.  Scratches his below the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A triple increase in ad revenue. Does get.  The man's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And winks at the silent hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't even double if yer figger it right. (to Quoyle) Point is.  A real reporter woulda named the obvious suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More obvious.  Than the wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer aunt, ya thick Statie lardface dumbass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle.  And Nutbeem.  Just look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets stiffed by the guy, after basin' her new shop on that revenue. And she ain't one ta fool with. Capable a anything, that woman! QUOYLE (angry now) Okay, where's the wife?  Agnis kill her too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, where's this week's shipping news?  Or you gonna rest on yer Crisco-coated laurels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle viciously BITES into his squidburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.  The way he's chewin', he ain't a fat boy t'be trifled with! NUTBEEM (quietly) His piece.  Is about oil tankers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Card blinks.  Looks at Quoyle with, dare we say, new resp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope fer ya yet.  Now that's news, the McGonigle oil field. Petrodollars, a golden flood a jobs. That's th'future a this god-forsaken ice rock.  Civilization!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scratches his crotch savagely.  To honor civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why those with half a brain already put our money where our mouths is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts his squidburger.  Where his mouth is.  Nutbeem clari Quoyle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two shares.  Of Mobil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE...brightly lit kitchen.  Bunny sits at the little t large mixing bowl filled with popcorn before her, little her side.  They are watching Freakazoid on a tiny TV.  Bu shovels in a mouthful of popcorn.  Then makes a sage, if unintelligible, comment about the show to Herry.  Still c she takes another huge handful of popcorn... ...Herry opens his mouth like a baby bird.  Bunny stuffs in.  It's a stare-and-chew, side by side.  Just alike. ANGLE...cozy parlor.  Quoyle sits in a Barca-lounger with bowl of chips in his lap.  He is watching hockey on a mod the action is fierce.  Stuffs his mouth full of chips, ye manages to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so there they were, this goofy old codger and his dog, big as life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to see Wavey now.  Curled on the sofa, under a She is knitting something in a heavy oxblood-colored wool watches her work. WAVEY (softly) That'd be old Nolan.  He's actually your uncle, last of the crazy Quoyles. I should have realized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps her eyes on her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sad, really.  Lives like a hermit in a run-down shack.  No one to look after h...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I was worried about Bunny night and day, and there's absolutely nothing wrong with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.  Which makes him uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her only problem is her dad worries too mu... WAVEY (not looking up) You are a loving and wonderful father. You're not the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She meant to reassure him.  Instead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is th...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks up with smoky eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...after all this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I've been workin' longer hours. So Dennis and Beety were kind enough to bring Bunny to the daycare.  Fed her a lotta meals, too.  They're real friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle's smile tries to sell the innocence of his absence WAVEY (very quiet) I thought you forgot.  That I'm your friend, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smile from her.  She wants him to know she was hurt. his head, serious now.  No, I didn't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want another sandwich?  There's roast pork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up what's left of his four-decker.  This is plen a huge bite to show how much he likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said.  You'd read me your article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did, he nods.  But just now he's scared to.  And so sh Which traps him.  He pulls out a single sheet of paper. throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody Hangs a Picture of an Oil Tanker.  That's the header.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.  Likes that.  He gestures, go back to your knit she smiles, slyly.  And commences to knit. QUOYLE (reads) There's a 1904 photo hung in the library.  Eight schooners heading out to fishing grounds, sails spread it like white wings.  Beautiful.  Beyond compare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This means something to him.  Hear it in his voice. QUOYLE (reads) More common today is the low black profile of oil tankers.  Like the ruptured Golden Goose, which last week bled 14,000 tons of crude onto seabirds, fish and boats at Cape Despond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops.  As if revisiting that little thought in his mi QUOYLE (reads) There will be more and more tankers. They will grow old and corroded, and their tanks will split.  They have already done to fishing.  What their spill has done to fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sneaks a glance.  She has never looked up. QUOYLE (reads) Nobody hangs a picture of an oil tanker.  On their wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  A full one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Whatcha think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reflects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think when Card sees it, he'll split a gut.  I think he'll sit up nights thinking of cheap shots to pay you back.  I think he'll never stop until you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle keeps nodding at each point.  Yep.  Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I haven't been so proud.  Of a friend.  Since I don't know when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle's heart explodes in his chest.  And shines in his There is a long silence. WAVEY (softly) Maybe another sandwich.  There's roast pork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swallows.  He just doesn't want to cry from happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Card.  Who is RIPPING the single page in half. again.  And again.  And again.  See Quoyle now, standing desk like a statue.  Billy and Nutbeem at their stations, as Card... ...flutters the pieces down onto his desk.  Like falling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll run it.  Just easier t'copy edit.  When yer can move th'pieces around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hush.  A frozen tableau in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run it.  Like I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does this suit yer, Quoyle? I'll do my job.  You do yers, which means a four-vehicle pile-up south a Killick-Claw.  And don't ferget the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides the battered camera across the desk.  They glar other a full beat.  Card belches, softly.  Quoyle takes t heads for the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fergot somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle turns.  Card doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pinko Greepeace sack a quivering pigfat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I leave out moosebutt-ugly? (nods to himself) You may go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on him.  Making a neat little pile of the torn piece

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAMM!  Across the room, Nutbeem stands.  Takes his cigar Passing Card's desk, on the way out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough love.  Impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAMM!  Card shoots Billy a challenging look.  You got so say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you get him fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can watch him beat yer to jelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just turns around.  Flicks ON his computer.  Back to work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny jumping out of the wagon, running to the house.  As locks his car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you leave the house open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up.  She is pushing the front door with one fing swings OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I keep the necklace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and lifts a long piece of TWINE.  There are KNOTS neat along its length.  Quoyle stares.  Stares. QUOYLE (calm) Sweetie.  Come sit in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle climbing the stairs in fading light.  He carries a iron.  Stops midway.  Listens to the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IF ANYBODY'S THERE, YOU BETTER COME OUT NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up, up, to the top.  Looking down the empty hall to see.. ...knotted twine.  At every door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle enters, haggard and distracted.  The place is lit, empty.  A toilet FLUSHES.  From the loo, appears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'tell me.  Yer fancy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding toward something behind Quoyle.  Turning, we see hanging over Card's desk is an oversized framed photo of: EYE - WORLD'S LARGEST OIL TANKER.  Quoyle stares blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said.  Nobody hangs those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Card just goes to the fresh stack of newspapers on his de one toward Quoyle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer column's front page stuff.  Only now, it's more like a caption, is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photo of the same tanker.  That hangs on Card's wall. QUOYLE (reads) More than 3000 tankers proudly ride the world's seas.  Even the biggest take advantage of Newfoundland's deep- water ports and refineries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spelled everthin' perfect.  So as not t'embarrass yer. QUOYLE (reading) Oil and Newfoundland go together like ham and eggs, and like ham and eggs they'll nourish us in the coming years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even put yer name on it. QUOYLE (finishes reading) Let's all hang a picture of an oil tanker.  On our wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stares at the paper.  In his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man a yer principles.  I unnerstan' resignation is th'only honorable course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle looks up.  Card flinches back.  But all that comes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can a man resign.  To nobody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drops the paper on the floor.  Steps on it, on his way to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If yer off to see Jack Buggit, yer'll hafta swim some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer can whine an' beg t'him.  But I runs his paper, every inch of it, every dirty time-eatin' job which he would have t'do without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' if yer think he's gonna choose you over fishin'...yer not as smart as even you look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cackle of the guy holding the straight flush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me an' Jack.  Has a sym-bi-otic relationship.  Yer can look that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle puts his hand on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the word, Card.  It means you two deserve each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the door.  It closes behind him.  Card alone, crosses in glee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'LL TELL JACK YER SAID SO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD on Card.  DISSOLVE TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a box of assorted doughnuts.  Two dozen.  A hand down toward a raspberry swirl, thinks better of it, moves thoughtfully along the selection to pluck a maple glaze, it to... ...Quoyle's mouth.  The box rests beside the cardboard ca which Quoyle is packing his things.  Nutbeem sits on the the desk, nibbling a cruller.  Billy is bringing three mu coffee.  Looks like a going-away party.  Through the glas only private office... ...Jack Buggit is talking.  Card is not.  Card stands now to the door, flings it OPEN.  Nutbeem taps Quoyle's shoul his pastry.  They look to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.  This is what Jack and I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking straight in Quoyle's eyes.  Defiant as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wanna run Quoyle's oil spill piece b'cause controversy sells papers and papers sells ads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds reasonable to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lives to needle this guy.  Card keeps his laser gaze on Q

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're gonna let Quoyle have his head on these columns, up to 500 words.  So he'll get his confidence up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's not go overboard.  He's rather green doncha thi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we wanna expand his responsi- bilities to boat crashes.  There's maybe four a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll need a raise.  And need to be represented in the negotia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And.  The oil tanker picture.  Stays!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nutbeem's eyes WIDEN.  He mimes catching an arrow shot th chest.  Falls OFF the desk. CARD (to Quoyle) All that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle looks him in the eyes.  Starts putting his things his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear the SLAMM! QUOYLE (never looks up) Jack's gone fishing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky threatens black.  Quoyle picks his way across the his ungainly, much-maligned boat, as it bobs against the dock.  He crouches, and as he begins to untie it, his gaz out toward the nearby point, and... ...something catches his eye.  A boulder in the shape of dog.  And as he stares, there is something below it.  Som a cove protected from intrusion by a jagged ring of menac rocks... ...it is a MAN in a yellow suit.  His head under the surf looking for fish.  Arms and legs spread out like a starfi body slides in and out of a small cave.  Tugged by the se top on a string. Quoyle stares in frozen shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline.  Reporter Becomes Magnet For Dead Men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way in past the pounding surf, the savage rocks.  So Q turns sharply.  Squints across the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was my panic?  He was already dead.  Maybe I thought, in some dim way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIMBS into his boat, TURNS the engine over.  KICKS it in toward the town across the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...if it wasn't too late for him. It wouldn't be for Petal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STREAKING out, toward the black sky.  Racing to open sea chop INCREASES drastically.  Closer.  Closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once I was past the shelter of the lee shore, and into the real wind. I realized my mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...clear of the point's protection, the wind ROCKS the ti swells coming BROADSIDE.  The boat RISES, then DROPS with speed.  Quoyle tries to swing the boat around, the propel the bow PITCHES violently, SLAMMING down, the stern SWAMP hull filling, swerving broadside just as the oncoming sea all its force, and the little boat... ...rolls OVER, Quoyle suddenly FLYING under water, limbs in all directions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline.  Reporter Becomes Anchor Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT...Quoyle's dad FLINGING him into the public pool youngster SINKING like an anvil in a profusion of bubbles CUT... BACK to Quoyle, struggling madly somehow to the surface, toward the overturned boat, GRASPING the stilled propelle which causes the bow to lift, the next wave turning the b upright, FILLING it with water, and it SINKS forever, as ...TUMBLES once more beneath the surface, watching the bo DISAPPEAR into darkness below him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid.  Stupid to drown with Bunny so young.  No life jacket, no floating oar.  No sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the surface, GASPING for air.  And then, daintily small boat, unaffected by the waves, her filmy dress ripp light breeze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it floats.  Just like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the lilting smile cruel?  Or only the irony that conve intimacy, even affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's filled with fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And VANISHES.  In her place, bobs a red BOX.  A plastic b cooler.  He LUNGES for it, GRIPPING the handles, resting on its top. The waves RISE, mountainous now, and he rises and falls w He has been swept a mile from the nearest shore. INTERCUT...a winch pulling part of the Geo, streaming mud swiftly flowing water.  Police and bystanders gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I wondered.  Am I going where she's gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK to the bay.  A barely-conscious Quoyle still clings the plastic cooler.  But hours have passed.  Light is fad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and will I see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns.  And there she is.  Beaming at him from the bow little rowboat, a smile ambiguous in the growing dusk.  I love.  From behind her a light GLOWS, giving Petal the as angel. She drops a wink.  FADES away.  And the light becomes... ...the BEAM from a fishing boat.  Quoyle squints his swol as strong hands WRENCH him from his box.  From the sea. warbles, distorted by wind and Quoyle's diminished consci

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Cockadoodle Christ!  I knowed somebody was out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle's teeth are chattering so hard, his body shivering painfully, Buggit hauls him over the rail and lays him do wriggling mound of fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank god fer yer figure, me old son. A thin man woulda froze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle burrows into the fish, like nestling in a down com Jack covers him with a heavy tarp.  Crouches down close..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Yer lost th'boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim light.  Quoyle stirs beneath the billowing down cover eyes flutter.  Open.  Where...? VOICE (O.S., very soft) It's all right.  You're in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head SNAPS around.  She's sitting just beside the bed shadow.  Her oxblood knitting across her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually.  It's just my bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he sees the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's not.  I just wanted to see your eyes bug out like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he sees the smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice was a croak.  So he CLEARS his throat with a ma disgusting effort.  It is gross and funny, and she smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I'm worried.  I don't worry much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rolls over, to see her better.  They are very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to, I'm all right. I'm in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried.  About you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  As he draws a breath to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the boys' room at Jack's house.  Wonder how long since Dennis slept here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances to the nightstand.  Beneath the dim lamp.  A Jack and blond son Jesson.  Guess what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Buggit called, knew Bunny was still with me.  The kids are camped out in the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.  You sittin' up with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A longer one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'okay.  Someday you'll do somethin' nice for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.  He will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you worried ab...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't find a second dead man. Just the rest of the first one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  He nods.  Well, that figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked.  Who you worried about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this, she stubs out her cigarette.  Takes another from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said Bunny talks to Petal at night.  You ever listen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.  Wouldn't be right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not that nice a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRIKES a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plays Petal.  Talks to the Barbies, like Petal talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brings her cigarette.  To the flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she's sorry she left them. It was just to see if they could be good girls.  And they were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and she loves them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes at once rapt and suffering.  She watches that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Barbies look better naked, Bunny looks good in blue, guess who said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draws on her smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we talked.  Just before Petal left her with that...stranger?  Bunny had snapped her mom's bead necklace. That's why she's making more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she's made enough.  She'll be forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears are pooling in his eyes.  Hers, too.  She keeps goi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She saves Petal a room at the house, but she's also got the key to the old place.  In case her mom would rather go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin stream of air escapes from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she talked about it.  Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I lied.  I said nice things about her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitter smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, there's only one problem. Petal isn't gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle thinking.  Madly.  What can he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're patient.  And we wait, and we're good to her. (beat) And.  Maybe.  Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares back.  Unease to match his own.  Maybe time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wiry wisp of an aged elf, ALVIN YARK is shaping the cen of what will become a tidy boat.  Its wooden skeleton acr sawhorses in his spacious workshop. ALVIN (sings softly to himself) Oh, the Gandy Goose, it ain't no use. It ain't no use, the Gandy Goose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle, Wavey and Dennis stand in a row.  Watching the li artisan shave wood as if his tools were his hands. ALVIN (keeps singing, as if alone) The Gandy Goose, she ain't no uuuuse... Cause all her nuts'n bolts is loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wavey can't help but smile.  She really likes the old duc ALVIN (never turning) See, I'm already buildin' yers in me mind.  The singin' helps that.  But. Gotta take a walk in the woods, find a spruce with jest th' right curve fer yer stem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And says no more.  Keeps working.  They are like acolytes feet of a guru who never bothers even to glance their way

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hurry up.  Thirty, forty years I'll be rarin' to get back out on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone smiles.  Except the guru.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta build her solid.  Who knows, mebbe Jack Buggit'll give his fishin' license to his boy.  So next time, won't be nobody to pull yer out. DENNIS (real quiet) Jack Buggit's boy is drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks.  Except the guru. ALVIN (cheery) Dennis.  Y'hear the one about the Newfie who lived ferever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His kid never got a fishin' license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he turns.  A maritime Yoda, squinting to discern if h is received.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we wait fer?  She's like the main stem.  Gives us our shape, doncha see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs his hand along the backbone of the boat he's buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death's one shape.  Fergiveness is another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crinkly old eyes, laser bright.  Dennis isn't angry.  Jus resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing 'bout waitin' on fergiveness? Mixes up who's waitin' on who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smile, no spin.  Just the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death is simpler.  An' a lot shorter wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the silence.  A door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Quoyle...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sprightly bird-like woman.  Wears apology and concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school is callin'?  It's about yer daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRINCIPAL is spare, dressed for England, her voice authoritarian by its pace, exaggerated diction, and lack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not only pushed Mrs. Lumball.  Not only pushed her very hard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated in a semi-circle around the desk of power.  Quoyle stricken, respectful.  Wavey, already pissed off at the p And Bunny,her hat and coat on, arms folded, face crimson

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knocked.  Her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand the severity of this, Mr.  Quoyle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And.  Refuses to explain her act.  Or. Apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right, young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances.  We have no choice but to suspend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny looks down.  Glaring an evil spell of death at her kneecaps. WAVEY (quietly) I think Bunny and I.  Should take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh.  Wavey?  If it's all the same to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle and Bunny alone, hand-in-hand, walking slow where picked berries.  Nobody's talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you gonna ask? QUOYLE (calm) When you're in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, that hasn't happened yet.  More walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She musta done something.  Really bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said like he means it.  Which he does.  And Bunny, squint sees that. INTERCUT...the crime.  Playground filled with kids.  Bunn girlfriends on the jungle gym.  Bunny the best, a natural MRS. LUMBULL large, sour, doughy, and betrayed by life, s her silver whistle in the midst of chaos.  Her thoughts o plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the worst one of all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Herry Prowse comes to tug at the teacher's wool co holding his crotch and jumping up and down.  This does no an advanced credential to interpret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herry told her he had to pee.  But the way he talks.  He could just say 'eeee,' like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lumbull looks down.  From her face as she responds, already devoted, over time, more professional attention t troublemaker than should be asked of any dedicated educat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told him that recess was almost over, an' she wasn't gonna make a trip special, an' he could hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herry, seemingly, disagrees.  Still holding his crotch, h and down with greater agitation.  She grabs him, rather r the arm.  Marches him over to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She made him stand against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and walks off, pointedly ignoring him from ten feet aw screams, pumping his fists in frustration.  Grabs himself suddenly.  Whether or not we can see the dampness spread, see his humiliation all too clearly.  As his tears come.. ...a figure BOLTS into frame from behind Mrs. Lumbull.  H over like a linebacker, full speed ahead, LAUNCHING herse the back of the large woman's knees.  Her feet go UP, and of her goes... ...DOWN like the proverbial amount of bricks.  Herry's te fast.  Watching the woman shriek, and keep shrieking.  Ma laugh.  CUT... BACK TO...the berry path.  They are sitting on a fallen l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, a good dad would say hitting is always wrong.  You coulda hurt her bad.  I guess you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't hurt for real.  Just screamed like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle pulls out a single Snickers bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I'd seen it.  It really sounds funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petal'll think so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.  Nods, probably will.  Peels the candy b its wrapper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there won't be any trouble at school.  I'II take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks the candy bar in half.  Tho not quite equally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the best thing about people. Is they can forgive each other.  I heard that this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That teacher.  Is gonna forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.  Oh, yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That.  And she won't want the story printed in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I don't wanna forgive her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out the two pieces of candy.  She takes them bot bigger one in his mouth.  As he chews...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to do it.  'Cept for Wavey, I'm the only family Herry's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nibbles at her own piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the ghost.  Who's not a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one who ties the knots?  You're the only family he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?  Her father doesn't react.  He's even stopped chew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And slowly.  Quoyle nods.  I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle picks his way down to the battered boat shed, hidd foot of his cliff.  He carries a big carton, which we see the journey slow and awkward.  Across the gravel now, to. ...the door.  HEAR the fire crackling, see the smoke curl Takes a breath.  Knocks softly.  Then LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE NOLAN?  CAN I COME IN?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Juggle the box, lift the latch.  Enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man and the dog huddled together at the fire.  Th over with red eyes.  Just alike.  Only one growls.  Quoyl smile, a soft voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle.  My daughter Bunny and I. We got you some hot bread.  And some meat.  Some dried fish.  Some squash and vegetables...a cake...some warm clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nolan is listening.  Sharp-eared, sharp-eyed.  What trick So Quoyle sets the carton down in the squalor.  Takes out fresh bread.  One step forward.  Lay it down. Good faith offering.  And... ...Nolan scuttles to it.  Like a wary crab.  He tears off of bread.  Nibbles.  He likes it.  And as he eats... QUOYLE (softly) You tied those knots, huh? At my house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...crouches down to the old man's size.  Almost close eno touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't yer house, it's th' Ouoyle house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's found the meat.  Ripped off a chunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I am Qu...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old ones.  Got run outta Omaloor Bay a hunnerd years ago.  Dragged that house across th' ice.  On spruce runners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuffs some into his face.  Like this, even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hadda lash it to th' rock.  She'll tell yer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course she never come t'see me. That's obvious why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Quoyle draws a breath to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Aunt Agnis Hamm, me son.  That's cause she can't face me.  I knows she killed 'im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.  Of stone silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That baby she was carryin'.  What was she t'do?  She wuz only 12.  An' it was her own brother what done 'er.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quoyle's wide-eyed shock. QUOYLE (numb) Her own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT...a tiny frozen pond.  Long ago.  A girl of 12, husky, skating alone.  We've seen her, in the photo at Qu dad's house.  And as she skates, she looks up to see... ...a boy of 15, stocky, sullen.  He was in the same photo now, he steps onto the ice.  Unbuttons his pants.  Begins toward her on the soles of his fishing boots.  She looks Snow banked on all sides of the pond.  Nowhere to run on skates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her brother, me son.  She only had th' one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl, breathless, skating this way and that.  The boy in, cutting off her angle.  A deadly endgame.  There are And... ...he is ON her.  Pulling her TUMBLING to the ice in SLO- No sound but their hot breath, the grunt of the struggle, CUT BACK to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course no one alive knows no more. So her an' me... (winks) Our.  Little.  Secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis and Mavis are showing Wavey their new shop.  It is bright with more elaborate fittings, the amount of work p carries the scent of success.  Quoyle trails behind, as A on Wavey like a prize new daughter-in-law.  When she turn sees her nephew staring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  My hem crooked?  As if I was wearin' a hem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was staring pretty intently.  Realizes that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I just come from seein' your cousin Nolan.  Guess I was thinkin' about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds his gaze with her own.  Is she wondering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Quoyle?  What do you think of my dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody turns on that one.  Mavis cuts her alter ego Ag look.  Can you believe this slut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wore it just for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She actually looks pretty good in it.  Wavey noticing tha Watching Quoyle say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was more consideration.  Than I deserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polite banter?  Or outright flirting?  Hard to tell if it or Agnis who disapproves more.  Dawn ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your aunt tell you about all the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis just blinks.  Can scarcely believe she heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis told us it came from Macau. AGNIS (quietly) Hush yoursel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...from Silver Melville.  And it was more than she expected.  And we shipped the chairs off to her. Y' know, the three remaining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A really frozen beat. QUOYLE (casual, to Agnis) Uh.  Why would she send you more tha... AGNIS (to Dawn) Do you have enough attention now, young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis echoes Agnis' glare. QUOYLE (really casual) Macau, huh?  So.  That where y'sent th' chairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnis turns.  Sizes him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's flatterin' you showin' me how you've turned into such a competent reporter and all.  But even if I remembered where I sent 'em.  I couldn't tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts her fingers to her lips.  Leans closer, to confide s he is obviously unaware of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professional ethics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Wavey, cooking flapjacks.  Talking to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only you.  Could do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she's not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fed him.  You gave him clothes. You're the first human ever was kind to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scoops them expertly into a stack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accordingly.  You're sick with guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serves them to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're not a complex guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Quoyle, who nods absently.  About the one thing he is Just now, he's examining the prodigious status of her oxb knitting.  Still attached to the needles, it looks too br a muffler. QUOYLE (decides) Horse blanket. WAVEY (ah!) That's what that is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if y'called around.  Musta found somepla... WAVEY (quietly) One decent golden age home.  It's in St. John's.  You can maybe afford it, tho God knows why you should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes the flapjacks closer to him, CLANKS down the f She's exasperated.  Thinks he's wasting his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't put him there, til I go down to St. John's.  See it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!  Let's not be rash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And everything.  Sorta.  Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, the kids could stay with Dennis and Beety.  Or Agnis, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meaningful beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why.  Would I.  Do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks deep in his eyes.  Hard to guess the answer she hear.  He clears his throat.  Looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  Remember when you said. Someday, I'd do something nice for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when he looks to her, she is... PETAL (Wavey's voice) And this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A witheringly sexy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  Overnight trip to St. John's. All expenses paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petal arches a delicate brow. PETAL (Wavey's voice) Overnight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blinks.  And sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with a weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a playful smile.  Of her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not London, but it might as well be.  Wavey and Quoyle at double-decker bus, wind whipping their hair.  She is watc big city flow past, drinking every inch of it.  He's watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorta.  Because of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, love.  Isn't about what's good for you.  Isn't about what you wish it was.  Isn't about what...would make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are swimming.  Can she possibly hear this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love.  Is about want.  What you really want.  And you can't change that.  Even if it's poison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
